page.title: 10Ecology of Therfield Heath
page.content: Therfield Heath is mainly grass, though there are trees and hedges. The soil is chalk. Water is trapped in a layer of greensand underneath. This is where our water comes from. There are woods, where hawthorn and other trees grow. Near Baldock Rd. are big horse chestnut trees, where we collect conkers in autumn. There are many sorts of grasses e.g. rye grass and wild flowers e.g.yarrow, plantains and buttercups. Some of the flowers are quite rare e.g. cowslips and pyramidal orchids. Sheep are still grazed on the heath. There are lots of small animals such as rabbits and voles and many more smaller animals e.g. worms and snails. Many birds visit the heath e.g.wood- peckers and warblers and the plants attract a variety of butterflies.
